edge: The film 'Thunderbirds' belongs to the science fiction genre, as it contains elements of scientific and imaginative imagination.
The film 'Thunderbirds' is an action-adventure movie, as it contains exciting and thrilling events that involve danger and uncertainty.
Jonathan Frakes is the director of the film 'Thunderbirds'.
William Osborne is one of the writers of the screenplay for the movie 'Thunderbirds'.
Michael McCullers is another writer who contributed to the creation of the script for the film 'Thunderbirds'.
The TV series 'Thunderbirds' was originally created by Gerry Anderson.
Jeff Tracy is the head of International Rescue, as mentioned in the movie 'Thunderbirds'.
Fermat is one of the friends who joins Alan to stop the Hood in the film 'Thunderbirds'.
Tin-Tin is another character from the movie 'Thunderbirds' who assists Alan and Fermat in their mission.
Alan Tracy is one of Jeff Tracy's sons and a member of International Rescue, as depicted in the film 'Thunderbirds'.
The Hood is the antagonist of the movie 'Thunderbirds', who plots against International Rescue and steals their vehicles.
International Rescue is an organization that helps people in dangerous situations, as portrayed in the movie 'Thunderbirds'.
The song 'Thunderbirds Are Go' by pop-rock band Busted is featured in the soundtrack of the movie 'Thunderbirds'.
The song 'Thunderbirds Are Go' by Busted ranked number one on the UK Singles Chart, as per the movie context.
The Tracy family operates International Rescue, a secret organization that aids during disasters using technologically advanced machines called Thunderbirds.
Operates International Rescue from Tracy Island in the South Pacific.
Attends Wharton Academy, a boarding school in Massachusetts.
Son of Jeff Tracy and a member of International Rescue.
Brother of Alan Tracy and a member of International Rescue.

Technologically advanced machines operated by the members of International Rescue.
Criminal mastermind who infiltrates Tracy Island and steals communication capabilities from Thunderbird 5, trapping its crew inside.

The vehicle used to rescue John from the space station Thunderbird 5 after communication capabilities are stolen by The Hood.

The Hood and his minions pilot the now-repaired Thunderbird 2 to London and use the Mole to sink a monorail line into the Thames and drill into the Bank of England’s vaults.

Alan and company escape and restore power to Thunderbird 5 before setting off in pursuit of The Hood in London. Arriving in London, Alan and Tin-Tin rescue the submerged monorail car using Thunderbird 4 before pursuing the Hood. The rest of the Tracy family return from space in Thunderbird 3 and confront The Hood at the Bank.
The Hood captures Jeff and Lady Penelope and challenges Alan to defeat him.
While Alan fights The Hood on a catwalk over the moving drill of The Mole,
Tin-Tin, who as his niece is also able to use his powers, defeats The Hood.
The Hood taunts Alan to let him die as his father did, but Alan rescues him, knowing that his father had actually tried unsuccessfully to save the Hood.
Alan, Fermat, and Tin-Tin are inducted as official members of the team.
During the sequence in which the Hood and his minions are arrested, director Jonathan Frakes has an uncredited role as a police officer.
PolyGram Filmed Entertainment purchased the rights to the entire ITC Entertainment library, which included the original Thunderbirds series.
Peter Hewitt was signed on to direct the film adaptation of Thunderbirds, as he was a lifelong fan of the series.

Karey Kirkpatrick was signed on to write the screenplay for the film adaptation of Thunderbirds, although he was not a fan of the original series and watched all 32 episodes of it to immerse himself within the lore of the series.
PolyGram Filmed Entertainment purchased the rights to the entire ITC Entertainment library, which included the original Thunderbirds series.
In the script written by Peter Hewitt and Karey Kirkpatrick, The Hood tries to steal Tracy Island's power core to power a device controlled by arch villain Thaddeus Stone.

In the script written by Peter Hewitt and Karey Kirkpatrick, The Hood's target for stealing the power core is to transfer all of Earth's gravity to the moon as part of a device controlled by arch villain Thaddeus Stone.
After Peter Hewitt left the production due to his dislike for the new direction the film was taking, Jonathan Frakes replaced him as director.
Jonathan Frakes, a big fan of the original series, was hired to direct the film adaptation of Thunderbirds.
Working Title, which was the unit of PolyGram that produced films in Britain, had concerns that the film would not play well in the US market.
concept artist Mike Trim created a design for an original pod vehicle named the 'Telehandler' for the film, but his work went unused.
Mike Trim's design for an original pod vehicle named the 'Telehandler' falls under the broader category of Original Pod Vehicles.
Brady Corbet played the protagonist role of Alan Tracy in the film.
Bill Paxton portrayed the character of billionaire ex-astronaut Jeff Tracy, who is Alan's father in the movie.
Bill Paxton's character in the film served as a 'father figure', teaching his sons, particularly his youngest son Alan, basic lessons of ethics and integrity about doing the right thing.
Ben Kingsley accepted the role of The Hood in the film as his children were fans of Thunderbirds, and he was ready for a more lighthearted role after finishing House of Sand and Fog.
Ben Kingsley portrayed the original villain character, The Hood, in the film.

Sophia Myles was cast as Lady Penelope, who would recall Frakes as 'lovely' and having a 'great, positive energy'. Much of her dialogue (and Ron Cook's as Parker) was rewritten by Richard Curtis, as it wasn't thought to be funny enough.
Steven Moffat offered Myles a role in Series 2 of Doctor Who because he watched the film with his son.
Anthony Edwards was cast as Brains, imagining it was a 'silly little kids' movie', but was impressed by Frakes' and production designer John Beard's 'reverence' for the original series.

The producers of Thunderbirds Are Go (2015) hoped Gerry Anderson would be a part of the production, but Jamie Anderson claims that he was 'kept at an arm's length' from the project and only offered a large sum of money to promote the film in the final stages of post-production, which he declined.

In the film, Tracy Island is referred to by name in dialogue and is associated with International Rescue.
In the film, 'Thunderbirds' is used to refer to International Rescue by the general public.
The Hood is mentioned in dialogue alongside Tracy Island.
In the film, there are changes to the design of both Tracy Island and the Thunderbirds fleet.
The Thunderbirds fleet has been redesigned along with the International Rescue uniforms.
In the film, Wharton Academy is identified as Alan's school.
The exterior of the fictional Bank of London is featured in the film.

The context describes how the film adaptation differs from the original series in terms of character nationality, secrecy rules for International Rescue, and setting. This suggests a relation of difference or variation between the two.

In the original series, Alan and the other Tracy brothers are closer in age. The context mentions that this is not the case in the film adaptation, indicating a relation of contrast or opposition between the two sets of characters.

The context explains that Fermat Hackenbacker and Onaha are new characters introduced in the film adaptation, with Onaha taking the position of Grandma Tracy, who is omitted from the film. This suggests a relation of substitution or replacement between these characters.
The context reveals that Tin-Tin and Kyrano change nationality from Malaysian to Indian in the film adaptation, indicating a relation of transformation or change between these two locations.

The context explains that International Rescue now allows itself to be filmed and photographed on missions, which was previously forbidden. This suggests a relation of modification or alteration between these two concepts.

Some promotional materials describe this version of Jeff Tracy as having set up International Rescue in the year 2010, while other materials suggest that the actual events of the film take place in March 2020. This indicates a relation of uncertainty or ambiguity between these two time periods.
The film 'Thunderbirds' had a worldwide gross of $28,283,637 and an estimated budget of $57 million, resulting in it being classified as a box office bomb.
The film 'Thunderbirds' was a commercial failure due to stiff competition from other films and poor critical reception.

node_2: lack of appeal for older audiences
edge: The Hollywood Reporter suggested that the poor performance of 'Thunderbirds' at the box office may be attributed to a lack of appeal for older audiences who remember the TV original.
The film "Thunderbirds" lacks the romantic approach to technology as compared to the original series, particularly mentioning its rushed version of the countdown to the Thunderbirds takeoff.
Thunderbirds received negative reviews.
The trend of making films based on decades-old TV series, including Thunderbirds, is regarded as good-intentioned but misguided.

Sukhdev Sandhu argues that the entire trend of making films based on decades-old TV series, including Thunderbirds, does not need reviving and updating as they can be seen on terrestrial and cable TV and are available on DVD.
Sukhdev Sandhu found the film's plot to be thin.
Amy Biancolli found the central character Alan to be whiny and uninteresting.
Amy Biancolli found the script of the film to be poor.
Amy Biancolli found the plot of the film to be contrived and unsatisfying.
Amy Biancolli found the acting in the film to be wooden.

Ian Freer, writing for Empire, assessed that the film fails to either evoke nostalgia in the generation which watched Thunderbirds as children or provide snappy entertainment for the current generation of children.
Like Sandhu, Ian Freer felt that the countdown sequence was so rushed that there is no sense of occasion to a Thunderbird taking to the sky.
